title: The Long Silence
outcome: Three days after the last event, the BCI goes silent—no scores, alerts, or restrictions are issued. Daily life continues, but uncertainty grows. The Council flounders as citizens realize the system’s grip is gone, leading to widespread calls for real democracy and exposing Halden’s last wish: a self-governing city.

events.description: BCI stops scoring residents without warning. For days, no alerts, restrictions, or service prioritization occur—most citizens experience no immediate impact.
Confusion grows as access to services and jobs becomes unpredictable. Council meetings become fractious, with blame exchanged and no effective response.
Neighborhood committees and informal networks emerge to coordinate community aid and problem-solving, beginning to replace BCI’s former influence.
Rada launches a citywide campaign to collect personal stories about life after the BCI, sparking hope for a new model of civic trust and participation.
Amid public rallies and open debate, the Council accepts that a citizen-led model is needed. A new democratic charter is drafted, marking the end of algorithmic rule.
